subject: Writing
title: Ernie Pyle: The Soldiers' Voice
description: A quick, practical guide to Ernie Pyle: The Soldiers' Voice.

hook.text: Ernie Pyle didn't interview generals. He slept in foxholes with infantrymen and wrote their stories.

buildup.text: Pyle covered World War II from North Africa, Italy, France, and the Pacific â€” always with ground troops.

discovery.text: His columns focused on ordinary soldiers â€” their fear, humor, exhaustion, and homesickness.

twist.text: He won a Pulitzer in 1944, but said he was too tired and scared to care about prizes.

climax.text: Pyle was killed by a Japanese sniper on Ie Shima in 1945. Soldiers mourned him like one of their own.

punchline.text: He told their stories so well, they called him family.

quiz.question: What made Ernie Pyle's war reporting distinctive?
options: He focused on ordinary soldiers, not generals
